trial_identification.studytitle: Launceston chickpea extended ad libitum consumption study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A cross-over trial of the effect of ad libitum supplementation of chickpeas in the diet on nutrient intake, physiologic or metabolic parameters, compared to an ad libitum diet only for the reduction in cardiovascular disease risk factors

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal development and function of the cardiovascular system

interventions.interventions: Sequential cross-over trial comparing the effects of a stated minimum amount of chickpeas per week (four 300g cans) with an unrestricted (usual) diet of the subject's choosing. Chickpea diet period was 12 weeks duration.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at the end of 4 weeks of observed usual diet, at the end of 12 weeks of the ad libitum chickpea diet, and after a further 4 weeks on the usual diet (weeks 4, 16 and 20)
Measured at the end of 4 weeks of observed usual diet, at the end of 12 weeks of the ad libitum chickpea diet, and after a further 4 weeks on the usual diet (weeks 4, 16 and 20)
Measured at the end of 4 weeks of observed usual diet, at the end of 12 weeks of the ad libitum chickpea diet, and after a further 4 weeks on the usual diet (weeks 4, 16 and 20)

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Results were measured at weeks 4, 16 and 20
Results were measured at weeks 4, 16 and 20
Results were measured at weeks 4, 16 and 20
Results were measured at weeks 4, 16 and 20

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Perceived degrees of satiety, perceived degrees of bowel health and function.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Results were measured at weeks 4, 16 and 20

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Middle-aged, healthy, recruited by newspaper advertisement who were willing to eat a chickpea supplemented diet for a 12 week period.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Those on lipid-lowering or anti-diabetic medication; intolerant to chickpea or wheat.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: School of Human Life Sciences, University of Tasmania

ethicscommitee.ethicname: HUMAN RESEARCH ETHICS COMMITTEE (TASMANIA) NETWORK: Medical
